January 23, 1948.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Your esteemed letter of January 15, has been duly received, and contents noted.

It is with deep regret that I must inform you that we have no Sisters available for the Indian School on the St. Regis Reserve. It would be a pleasure for us to be associated with you in this great work, but I am sorry that it is impossible for us at the present time. I hope that you may be able to find another Community of Sisters who will be able to carry on this work better than we can.

I am very happy to learn that you are pleased with the work which is carried on at Eskasoni.

With best wishes for the success of your great work,

I am, dear Sir,

Yours respectfully,

Sister M. Ignatius
Superior General.
January 29, 1948.

Mr. T. L. Bonnah, Indian Agent,
Box 937, Cornwall, Ontario.

Dear Miss Searson:

You will recall our previous correspondence concerning the new Indian Day School at Chenail.

Mr. Bonnah was in the office yesterday and advised me that he will also have a vacancy at the Cornwall Island East School. As this is closer to Cornwall and has good transportation facilities, we decided to advise you of this vacancy also, in the event that it would suit your requirements better than the Chenail School.

Our new salary schedule has been approved and we can now offer you a higher rate than previously. If you wish details concerning the Cornwall Island School, I would suggest that you write directly to Mr. Bonnah.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Hyndford, Ontario.

BFN/IM.
Reverend Mother General:

Chenail Indian Day School.

I have just returned from an inspection trip to the Indian Schools of the St. Regis Agency.

I attended the commencement exercises at the St. Regis Village School and was particularly impressed with the progress made by the children under the skilled guidance of the good Sisters presently in charge. These children not only graded well in the achievement tests which I administered but their deportment and bearing is a great credit upon the work done there by the Sisters of St. Ann.

I took an opportunity of having these Sisters visit the new two room school with attached teacher's quarters which has just been completed on the Chenail section of the St. Regis Agency. I will say no more except that I feel that these teachers were impressed with the very modern building which we have erected.

I feel that it would be to the benefit of the Church, the Indians and the Department if we could persuade the Sisters of St. Ann to assume the responsibility of teaching the children in the area served by this new school. We would have approached you long ago with this proposal but have hesitated because we could not offer your Sisters the Daily Mass required by your Order.
We would be glad to offer one large basement room for conversion as a chapel. I have discussed this matter with Reverend Father Jacobs S.J., and I understand that he will try to personally bring to your attention the advantages which would be yours if the Sisters of St. Ann could accept this new mission field.

Very sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Reverend Mother General,
Mother House of Sisters of St. Ann,
Lachine, P.Q.

Re: Cheneil School

Replying to your letter of the 15th, file 33-3-1 (E), please be advised that the Mother Provincial visited the new school on Thursday the 15th. I endeavoured to obtain from her something definite but was unable to do so. She advised me, however, she would notify you within a few days.

My personal opinion is that they would much rather take over a year from now when they would have an opportunity of getting everything prepared. However, we should keep in mind that if the Sisters of Service or St. Martha are available in a year from now, it would seem more advisable to accept their services. I would suggest that if you do not receive a definite commitment from the Sisters by the time you receive this letter, arrange to hire Miss Comeau and stall the Sisters off until the fall of 1949. In the meantime, we might get favourable news from the Sisters of Service.

Chenail Indian Day School.

Reverend Mother General:

Further to my letter of June 24, I wish to advise you that we have found it necessary to appoint two lay teachers to the above school.

In view of the present serious shortage of Catholic teachers, the Department had to take advantage of the availability of two such teachers, before they were hired elsewhere by School Boards.

However, I understand that you have been carefully considering the proposals made in my letter during the past month. I do hope that you will be able to reach a favourable decision by the 1949-50 academic year.

I still feel that it would be to the benefit of all concerned if the Sisters of Saint Ann could assume the responsibility of teaching the children in the area served by this new school. Even though we have had to abandon our plans for this step for the 1948-49 year, I earnestly hope that we can make suitable arrangements with you for next year.

Very sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Reverend Mother General,
Mother House of Sisters of St. Ann,
Lachine, P. Q.

Lachine, Que., July 27, 1948.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Your letter dated June 24, File 33-1-1 (E), in which you ask the Sisters of St. Ann to take charge of the St. Regis Chénail School, was given due consideration. I regret to have been unable to give you an earlier reply, as a special authorization received but yesterday was absolutely required for acceptance.

I am happy to tell you that our Order, always desirous of cooperating in the good work done among Indians by the Society of Jesus and the Department of Indian Affairs, accepts to staff this school.

I am sure, though, that you are fully aware, just as we are, of the difficulties to be encountered in this new mission field. We then confidently rely on you to supply the needs of our sisters, both temporal and spiritual, and to render such conditions of life acceptable to them so that their work be of benefit to all concerned.

In closing, I wish to thank you for the laudatory remarks you wrote regarding the work done by our sisters at the Saint Regis Village School.

Hoping that this new state of affairs will turn to the satisfaction of all parties concerned, I remain

Very devotedly yours,

[Signature]
Superior General
Sisters of Saint Ann
General Administration
Lachine, Que.

July 29, 1948.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Our letters of recent date regarding the Chemail Indian Day School crossed on their way as yours was received just as mine had been mailed to you.

I understand that our acceptance to staff the Chemail School for the coming academic year as stated in my letter of July 23 is cancelled by the fact that you have already hired two lay teachers. As you reiterate your request for our services, I wish to say that our decision to cooperate with the Department of Indian Affairs in the sublime work of Education among the Indians is not revoked, and we shall be most happy to assume the responsibility of teaching the Indian children of the Chemail area for the 1949-50 academic year.

The two sisters for the Chemail School had already been appointed but they have now assumed duties elsewhere, and I am glad that a year's postponement is afforded us as the lack of subjects in our Community obliges us in many cases to limit our activities.

Wishing you success in all your undertakings, I remain

Very devotedly yours,

[Signature]
Superior General
Chenail Indian Day School.

Reverend Mother General:

I have for answer your letter of July 29 and sincerely regret that we were forced to take action in hiring two lay teachers before the receipt of your previous letter of July 27.

However, we will regard your offer of two teachers for the 1949-50 academic year as a definite commitment.

We will make arrangements to transfer the two lay teachers elsewhere and will be very pleased to hand over the responsibility of teaching these Indian children to the Sisters of St. Ann on the first of September, 1949.

I am glad to hear that you have been able to assign elsewhere the two Sisters whom you intended to appoint to the Chenail School. I only hope that this year's postponement of our plans will not delay the educational advancement of these Indians.

I look forward to an opportunity of visiting you at Lachine in the near future and of discussing with you the situation both at St. Regis and at Caughnawaga.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Rev. Sister Mary Leopoldine, S.S.S.,

It would be appreciated if this matter could be attended to immediately as it is very difficult to keep harmonious relations these days with conditions like that existing. Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

While your letter of March 18th, file 1-1-1X (E), mentions that the Sisters of St. Ann will be taking over the Chenail School in September next, I had not heard anything definite from the Sisters. In the absence of definite information, I have requested Sister Zita some time ago to take up with her superior the question of the Chenail School. I have now received a letter from the Provincial Superior. When the Superior was at St. Regis last Fall, this matter was discussed and it seemed that unless the Sisters could have Mass in the Chenail every morning, they would not be able to stay there. The suggestion was made by the Superior that they should live at St. Regis and be driven to and from their work as is done in some of the rural schools at Dorion, Saraguay and St. Jerome. At the same time, an arrangement would be worked out whereby the girls from the Village could be taken to the Chenail to participate in the Sewing and Cooking classes. To do this, however, I should imagine, would require a station wagon.

I had suggested to the Superior that it would be a good thing if it were possible for the Sisters to take an interest in the younger women after school hours. In her letter, the Superior suggests the appointment of a Principal who, together with the two teachers employed in the Village and two in the Chenail, would mean five teaching Sisters staying at the Residence in the Village.
The Superior suggests that a Principal would be in a position to help the other Sisters by coaching backward pupils and also teaching Sewing and Cooking as well as organizing sewing groups among the younger women in the Village.

I do not know what the policy of your office is concerning the transportation requested by the Superior but I should like to add, however, that I have made no commitments whatsoever to the Sisters in this regard. Whether or not the sewage disposal system at the Village will accommodate additional Sisters, I do not know. The lot is so small that there is hardly room to get a truck in to bring in the fuel and, of course, the disposal bed had to be cut to a minimum.

As it would seem there are many things to be straightened out yet, I believe it would be advisable to have a definite understanding before we think about placing any of our other teachers. I shall be pleased to hear from you concerning the above.

[Signature]

P. L. Hornah,
Superintendent,
St. Regis Agency.

Chenail Indian Day School

Reverend Mother General:

This will confirm our conversation in which it was mutually agreed that the Sisters of St. Ann would not assume responsibility for staffing the above Indian Day School on the St. Regis Reserve this year.

I have just finished a long distance phone conversation with Mr. Indian Superintendent Bonnah, and I have advised him concerning our understanding. He is arranging for lay teachers for this school for the 1949-50 academic year.

If and when conditions improve at this school both concerning the provision of electricity and also concerning the religious facilities required by your Order, then I will write you again concerning this school.

In conclusion, may I extend to you and to the Reverend Sisters of your administration my thanks on behalf of the Department for the work which you have done in Indian Education in the past and with the hope that our mutual good relations will continue for many more years to come.

Very sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Casey,
Superintendent of Education.

General Administration
Lachine, Que.

June 23, 1949.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

My dear Sir:

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, File 306-1 (E), in which you officially confirm our previous mutual agreement in respect to the Staffing of the Chenail Indian Day School on the St. Regis Reserve this year.

I wish to express to you our sincere appreciation for the kind attention and satisfactory solution you brought to the problem concerning the above mentioned School. I also wish to assure you once more that the Sisters of Saint Ann are always willing and happy to cooperate with the Department of Indian Affairs in the good work done among the Indians when proper facilities are made available for them.

May your untiring efforts towards improving the educational and social conditions of the Indian children be ever crowned with success and may you fully enjoy the reward that commonly derives from devotion to a good Cause!

Yours very devotedly,

[Signature]
Superior General

ATTENTION: Mr. Bernard W. Neary

During our recent telephone conversation, you will recall the differences which have arisen between Miss Comeau and Miss Francis of the Chenail School was discussed. At the close of the school term, the teachers concerned do not appear to have made any reconciliation. Prior to school closing, this matter was discussed with each teacher with a view to having them mend their dispute. It was pointed out that disputes between teachers would eventually have a detrimental effect upon children and we were not in a position to condone a situation of that nature. A few days before school closed, the matter was again discussed with Miss Comeau and she stated that while she would like to return to the Chenail School she doubted very much if she would if the same arrangement existed between her and Miss Francis. In other words, if Miss Francis teaches at that school next year, Miss Comeau will likely not be here. While it is difficult to get at the root of their dispute, information obtained would lead me to believe that the teachers concerned are making a mountain out of a molehill and neither is willing to admit their fault.

As previously advised, it may be possible that Miss Francis may enter religious life and, if so, perhaps another teacher could be hired to take her place. Whether or not there would be agreement between them is difficult to say.
Knowing the local circumstances, and in view of our telephone conversation, I approached Miss Chisholm of the Cornwall Island East School to learn if she might be willing to go to the Chenail School if arrangements could be made to employ her sister. I understand the two sisters get along very well together. With an arrangement of this nature, we might then be in a position to put Miss Francis at the Cornwall Island East School. As I previously mentioned to you, I hate to see Miss Chisholm leaving the Cornwall Island East School as she is badly needed there and I know she would like to return. In view of the situation, however, and if matters do not right themselves, Miss Chisholm would go to the Chenail School providing her sister was appointed to that school also. In discussing this situation with Miss Chisholm, I have made no commitments that might alter any plans you have in mind. The matter was merely discussed with her with a view to finding, if possible, a solution in the event that Miss Comeau and Miss Francis could not be reconciled to teaching in the same school. Insofar as the latter two are concerned, both are, in my opinion, good teachers. I do not think, however, that Miss Comeau would be interested in teaching in an eight-grade school and she has expressed that opinion to me already.

You might let me have your views concerning the above.

T. L. Bonnah,
Superintendent,
St. Regis Agency.
July 5, 1949.

Chenaill Indian Day School.
Cornwall Island East Indian Day School.

Reference your 6-1 (33) of June 29

In view of the information contained in your letter, it would not be to the advantage of the Department to have Miss Francis and Miss Comeau teach in the same school next year.

I think your suggestion of having the two Misses Chisholm at the Chenaill School is a sound one if Miss Comeau can be persuaded to take the Cornwall Island East School.

If not, then the new Miss Chisholm and Miss Comeau could handle this school while the other Miss Chisholm could continue at Cornwall Island East.

I suggest you mention this matter to Miss Comeau and ascertain her reaction.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

In answer to your letter of June 10th, file 306-1(E) and July 5th, file 306-1(E), please be advised that we have been advised by Miss Comeau that it is her intention "to continue on at Chenail School next year with my former class and with a teacher who would help to keep existing the harmony you mentioned which is essential in any school".

Insofar as Miss Francis is concerned she advises today she is interested in teaching in the Junior room of the Chenail School. She was very interested to know if Miss Comeau was returning to the Chenail School and received the only answer we are at present in a position to give her.

After reviewing all the facts at your disposal you may deem it advisable to go ahead with plans to have Miss Comeau and Miss Chisholm take over the Chenail and Miss Christeen Chisholm at the Cornwall Island East School. Incidentally, Miss Francis was asked if she would be interested in the latter school and she replied in the negative.

If you deem it advisable, perhaps a position might be offered Miss Francis in another agency. We have had no complaints here as far as her work is concerned.

Cornwall Island East Indian Day School

Reference your 6-1 (33)

I note from the contents of your letter that both Miss Comeau and Miss Francis are interested in returning to the Chenaill School - but not together.

Unfortunately, we do not have any attractive positions in Ontario which are vacant for Miss Francis just at this time.

Please speak to her concerning her interest in a school in the Prairie Provinces. We have a real shortage of teachers there, and if she would like to try a school there for a year, I could arrange a transfer at once.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Referring to your file 306-1 (E), July 25th, please be advised that I have consulted Miss Francis with regards to accepting a position in the Prairie Provinces. As this, perhaps, came as a surprise to Miss Francis, she was not in a position to reply at the moment but stated she would give me a definite answer in a few days. I doubt, very much, if a position so far from the Reserve would appeal to Miss Francis.

It is most unfortunate that we can not find a place to open a classroom at the west end of Cornwall Island until we can get another school built in which case we could put Miss Francis in charge of the junior grades.

While I have not discussed this matter with Miss Francis, I would like to suggest that, to relieve the situation at the Cornwall Island West School, Miss Kelly be placed in charge of the senior grades teaching a shift from 8:30 a.m. to 12:00 noon. Miss Francis could be put in charge of the junior grades and teaching a shift from 1:00 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. In this way, I feel quite sure that the children will get much more attention than they are able to get under our present system and it will be a lot easier on the teacher. Present indications are that we would have even a greater attendance at the Cornwall Island West School in September and, with two teachers working on the basis as noted above, I believe we would be in a better position to carry on until a new school can be opened.

You might advise me concerning the above at an early date.

T. L. Bonnah,
Superintendent,
St. Regis Agency.
Miss Margaret Kelly,
Venosta, P.Q.

Dear Miss Kelly:

As you are aware, we are planning to erect a new school at Cornwall Island West to provide an extra classroom in addition to the present building. It has been recommended that in order to relieve your present heavy teaching load, we plan to operate two shifts pending the completion of the new building. These shifts would operate as follows:

(a) the senior pupils, under your teaching, from 8.30 a.m. to 12.15 or 12.30 p.m. daily,

(b) the junior pupils, under Miss Francis, from 1.00 p.m. to 4.30 p.m. daily.

I would appreciate your immediate acceptance of the above proposals as I believe the suggestion is in your own best interests as well as that of the pupils of Cornwall Island West.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Ottawa, March 2, 1936.

Dear Miss Billings:

With reference to your letter of the 27th ultimo, the Department considers it inadvisable to close an Indian day school on any of the regular school days, unless there is some very serious reason, such as the illness of the teacher. We expect Indian children to attend school regularly, and, whether they do or not, our schools must be kept in regular operation, as an example to the Indians. You may, however, close the school early enough on Friday afternoon, March 6th, to enable you to catch the afternoon train for Ottawa.

I phoned the Colonial Coach Lines this morning and find that you can leave here at 10:30 Sunday morning, next, and return to Cornwall by Prescott. They further inform me that it is possible that on next Sunday there will be a coach going direct from Ottawa to Cornwall. As intimated in the first paragraph of this letter, you should make arrangements to return to St. Regis in time to open the Chenail School at the regular hour on the morning of Monday, March 9th.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, May 3, 1909.

The Deputy Supt. General,

Mr. Agent Long forwards a resolution from the Chiefs of the Cornwall Island band in council, requesting the Department to repair and reopen the Chenail Indian school.

For many years there was a school in operation there, but it was closed thirteen years ago, chiefly on account of small attendance and in the expectation that Indians who desired to do so would send their children to the school in St. Regis village. This expectation has not been realized and the children from this section of the reserve have ever since then been growing up in ignorance.

It is not stated in the census return how many children of school age there are in this locality but in the resolution the number is given as between 30 and 40. If this estimate is correct, it seems unfair that they should be deprived of the means of receiving some schooling. It is claimed that the distance is too great for them to possibly go to St. Regis and even if they could do so they would have to cross water, which would endanger the lives of small children. I consider that the application of the Chiefs is worthy of attention and would suggest that someone from the Department should visit the place and make a full report on the situation, which should
state definitely the condition of the old building and verify the claims of the Indians for the re-opening of the school.

Mr. Public School Inspector Gilman endorses the application and in the meantime the Agent should be advised that full enquiries will be made. If it is decided to reopen the school, it will be done after the summer holidays.

MEMORANDUM:
Asst. Deputy Supt. General.

On Wednesday, the 28th ultimo, I went to the Chenail on the St. Regis Reserve. The Indians had requested the Department to repair and re-open the school there, which has been closed for the past thirteen years. There were a number of Indians present to meet me and they all expressed the wish that the Department would give them a school as their children, up to the number of about 35, are growing up in ignorance; there being no school near enough for them to attend.

I consider the request of the Indians should be acceded to as I am satisfied that a school is needed at this point.

The old school building can be repaired for an outlay of about $200.00. It fronts on the main road and is centrally located for all the Chenail Indians, as well as those living on Yellow Island directly opposite. The building is 16' 8" X 23' 8" X 8' 6" inside measurement, and is 18' at the gables and 10' at the sides outside.

The following repairs require to be made:

A new foundation all round, sunk 3' below the level and 18" above the ground.

Sills repaired, where necessary.

Roof re-shingled. Outside clapboarded over tar-paper.

New Front Door 2' 9" X 6' 9".
There are 6 windows 2' 9" X 3' 10". New sashes are needed for two of the windows; new stops for the others.

New floor laid over the old one.

Closets, Coal bins and desks would also be required.

The frame of the building is in good condition with the exception of a portion of the sills.

One of the Indians, Mr. Alex. McDonald, of the Chenail offered to do this work for $175.00 but Mr. Agent Long told me that he had neither the material, tools or experience to do the work properly, and he advised me to see a builder in Cornwall. I called on Mr. Smith, the Member, who recommended me to Atchison & Co., Saw Mill Owners and Contractors. I saw Mr. Atchison and he told me that if requested to do so he would give a detailed Estimate, and if he undertook the work would have it completed in time to open the school this Fall. I would suggest that Mr. Atchison be communicated with, as even if the Indians were given the work, the Department would have to go good for the material, and it is doubtful if it would be completed in time or done satisfactorily.

The Indians expressed themselves as willing to take advantage of the school if re-opened and were willing to have the regulations enforced if necessary.

Memorandum:—

Mr. Pedley.

Acting on instructions I left Ottawa on Monday, the 17th instant, for St. Regis, going by way of Hogansburg.

On our return we called on the Chenaill School which we charge of Mrs. Sarah Back. I found 26 children present: 13 boys and 13 girls. The school room has a seating capacity for only 36 and there are 51 children on roll. If the new school is built it will relieve this one, as many of the children would be able to attend it.

Mrs. Back is doing good work and is popular with the Indians. I found the room was very drafty and I recommend that the building should be provided with double windows before the next winter sets in. A map of Province Quebec should be sent them as the one they have is in French and the teaching is in English.

(Sd.) Martin Benson

Ottawa, April 18, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, in which you request to be informed as to whether grant will be allowed for the purchase of prizes for distribution to the pupils of the schools on the St. Regis Reserve.

In reply I beg to say it would appear that the last year on which a grant for prizes was allowed was at the closing of the schools for the summer holidays, 1915. The Department will approve of an expenditure for the purpose as follows:—St. Regis Village $12.00; St. Regis Island $8.00; Chenail, $8.00; Chetlain $6.00 and Cornwall Island $8.00. The prizes should be awarded upon the closing of the schools for the summer holidays and I would suggest that they be given to those pupils who have been most regular in attendance during the school year.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred for each school separately, but the amount expended should not exceed that authorized above for each school.

Your obedient servant

EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON THE CHENAIL SCHOOL, SEPTEMBER 25, 1923.

School building in very poor condition.
Foundation stones coming out.
Poor catches on door so that it is opened and shut with difficulty.

The door of the boys' closet is off its hinges and the seat broken.
No latch to keep the door of the girls' shut.

James Mabon,
Insp.
Ottawa, October 4th, 1923.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Chenail Indian Day School, draws attention to the condition of the foundation. He states that the stones are falling out. He further states that the catches on the door are in very poor condition, and that the door is opened and shut with difficulty, also that the door is off the boys' closet and the seat is broken, and there is no latch to keep the door of the girls' closet shut.

I have to request that you will arrange as soon as possible to have the repairs mentioned by the Inspector carried out. You should purchase any material required, and arrange for the labour in having the foundation under the building repaired. You should also see that the catches on the door are repaired, and that the repairs required to the boys' and girls' closets are carried out. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred by you, and properly certified vouchers should be forwarded covering the cost. These repairs should be completed at as early a date as possible.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.

Ottawa, January 15, 1924.

Sir:

The teachers of the Chetlain and Chenail Indian day schools called at the Department today on their way back to resume duties. As you are aware, they have been absent from duty since the schools re-opened after the Christmas holidays on account of having contracted the itch from the pupils.

Both these teachers state that if they are supplied with a quantity of antiseptic soap and ointment they will instruct the mothers of the Indian pupils to use the same with a view to eradicating this infectious disease. I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange for the purchase and delivery to the teachers of 4 dozen cakes of Parke-Davis antiseptic soap and 4 dozen 4 Oz. jars of sulphur ointment. You can obtain these from some druggist. You should obtain accounts, in duplicate, which please attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and send to the Department, when payment will be made. Both these teachers have been informed that when these supplies arrive they may arrange to close their schools for one day in order to visit the homes and instruct the mothers in the use of the antiseptics.

Your early attention to the purchase of the above should be given.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. E. Tarillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, June 15th, 1925.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Chenail and Chetlain Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the closets. He states that they should receive attention at an early date.

Please arrange to have the closets at both of these schools thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good sanitary condition during the coming summer holidays. No unnecessary expense should be incurred.

The Inspector also recommends that the walls and ceiling of the Chetlain School be cleaned. Please report regarding the cost involved in having any work which you recommend carried out at this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.
Sir,

In my examination of the correspondence which has accumulated at this office recently I find a letter from you dated June 15th re the above mentioned School and the repairs needed, and on my visit to this district on the 15th inst I took the opportunity of examining it and I find that the Closets need cleaning and a little repair, the Windows also need attention as there is not a particle of Putty remaining on any of them. A good sized piece of stone has fallen from the corner of the foundation, and the Entrance door is falling to pieces.

These repairs are needed if only to save fuel, and could be done at a small cost by one of the Indians living close to the School. Respectfully submitted

Mr. J.D. McLean  
Assistant Deputy Minister  
Indian Affairs.

Frederick Syme  
Detective Sergeant  
R.C.M.P. Police  
St Regis Reserve.
Ottawa, July 24, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, relative to the repairs required to the Chenail Indian Day School, comprising the reputting of the windows and the repairs to the foundation and the entrance door, as well as the cleaning and repairing of the closets. In reply I have to say that you may arrange with some competent person to have the above work carried out, if possible before the school re-opens after the present summer holidays. Please keep any expenditure for the purpose down to the lowest possible point. When the work is completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, on the forms for that purpose, in favour of the person who was engaged to carry it out. When these vouchers are received, a cheque in payment will be sent.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

The Acting Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P. Q.

St. Regis, Que.

Sir,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, relative to the repairs required to the roof of the Chenaill Indian Day School and to the painting of same. Your letter crossed ours of the same date in which you were authorized to arrange to have the roof of this building reshingled.

You should arrange for the purchase of the shingles, obtaining competitive prices, if possible, from the firm quoting the lowest price. You should see that a good grade of singles is obtained. You may also purchase the shingle nails required. As requested, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the shingles, etc., and also proper vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the labour in reshingling the roof of the building.

You should also state whether any painting is required to the interior of the building, and, if so, the cost of the work should be stated. Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of painting the exterior and interior of the Chenail Indian Day School building, and the quantity of paint, etc., required.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have this work carried out during the week beginning the 23rd instant, as it is noted the teacher will be absent on leave during that period. You should arrange for the purchase of the quantity of paint, brushes and other materials required. You should see that a good grade of paint, etc., is obtained. If possible, competitive prices should be obtained from a number of firms and the purchase made from the firm quoting the lowest price. You should also arrange for competent labour to do the work, which should be carried out to your satisfaction and under your supervision. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to make the best arrangements you can to have this painting completed and at the lowest possible cost, having in view the performance of a satisfactory job. When the work has been completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the paint and other materials and for the labour in having the work done.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Miss. Elena Fitzpatrick, teacher of Chemail Indian Day School, requests that one water pail and a clock be supplied for use at this school.

With reference to the clock, I may say that the alarm clock that was in use at this school, is out of commission. I had this clock repaired once before, and I don't consider it worth repairing again. Alarm clocks at schools don't seem to stand long, I expect due to getting knocked on the floor, etc. A wall clock is more satisfactory, and cheapest in the end. A good reliable clock can be purchased for around ten or twelve dollars, and would recommend one purchased for this school.

If purchase of clock is approved, please authorize me to purchase one. At present Miss. Fitzpatrick is using my timepiece.

July, 6th. 1931.

Sir.-

In reply to your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to Voucher No. 1290 amounting to $5.25 in favour of Smith Hardware Co., Cornwall Ont., goods for Chenail Indian Day School, and to the last item on the account, viz:-

"Paid Indian for 2 lots. --- $1.00"

I beg to say that when I am authorized to purchase certain school supplies I make out a list of goods wanted, hand it to an Indian, generally the mail carrier, Angus Latour, and gets the goods in Cornwall, and is paid by the company from whom goods are purchased for carting goods from Cornwall to St. Regis. If the order is a small one he is paid 25¢. If a large one 50¢.

In this case the company, Smith Hardware, omitted noting on a previous account, 50¢ for cartage. The Indian was paid for carting two lots, and which was marked on this particular account.

I may add, that when school supplies are transferred from Cornwall to St. Regis, that there is yet a charge for delivery to the schools. If the school is a long distance from St. Regis, such as Chetlain School or St. Regis Island School, I generally have the supplies delivered for 50¢, or if it is in the fall or early spring, sometimes I am obliged to pay 75¢.

If I was to hire an Indian to make a trip to Cornwall for school supplies, it would cost $2.00 or more, but by having the cartage done through the mail carrier, Angus Latour, I get it done much cheaper.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I beg to submit a report of St Regis Council meeting, July 4th.

The question of having a well dug at Chenail Day school for the use of the children at this school discussed.

Chief Dick Lazore and Mitchell Lazore, Chenail Indians offered to dig a well, including the stoning of it, and guaranteed water for $60.00.

The council considered this a very reasonable charge for digging a well, and recommended a well be dug at Chenail school.

With reference to the digging of a well at Chenail school, I beg to say that there should be a well at this location, rather than have the children at Chenail School obliged to drink water from the river most of the year.

There is a dug well near this school, on Mitchell Buckshott's property, but this well does not hold out all year round, it goes dry every winter.

If a good well could be dug and stoned for $60.00 I think it would be money well spent.

W. A. MacGibbon,
Agent.
Ottawa, July 20, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, submitting the report of the St. Regis Council in which the Indians offer to dig a well at the Chennail Indian Day School and guarantee an adequate supply of water, including the stoning, for the sum of $60.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging for the digging of this well, and it should be at a suitable location near the school. You should employ Indians who are out of work to perform the labour. The Department will allow payment at the rate of $1.50 per day for supplies while they are engaged in the work. It is to be understood, however, that each man employed will do a fair day's work. You should keep proper time sheets, in triplicate, of the labour employed, and these should be signed by the individual labourers and properly certified by you. You should also forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the supplies furnished the men employed. These accounts should show separately the supplies issued to each man. You should see that a satisfactory job is completed and that the well is properly stoned. You may purchase and have installed any equipment necessary to complete the well and place it in a good, serviceable condition. If possible, you should keep the cost within the above stated amount, viz., $60. The work in digging and stoning the well should be carried out before the school reopens.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

N. A. MacGibbon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P.Q.
Referring to your letter of the 20th July last in reference to the digging of a well at Chenail Indian Day School I beg to say that I took this matter up at the Council Meeting on the 8th inst.

Your letter states $1.50 per day for food supplies while engaged in digging the well, but you do not state what daily wage the workmen are to get, unless you expect the work done just for the food supplies supplied.

Chief Dick Lazore and Mitchell Lazore, Chenail Indians who are interested in having a well at this school, and who need work, say that they are prepared to commence the well at a daily wage of $1.50 each, or they would dig the well at $2.00 per feet, including the stoning of it.

I think the $2.00 per foot would be the best offer, for if they could not go deep enough to strike water, it would be their own lock out. However either by the day or by the foot should not cost a great deal.

The Indians say that around Chenail School, that water can be got at a depth of about 20 Ft, but that there is a possibility of striking quick sand. If quick sand was struck at near the finish of the well, this would mean some lumber for boxing purpose. If any lumber would have to be purchased for this purpose, it would be understood that the Department would pay for it.

This is about the best I can do on this well question.

Please advise me if you wish this well commenced on either of the above terms.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, August 12, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, with reference to the digging of a well at the Chenail Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the $1.50 per day allowed for food supplies while the Indians were engaged to perform the labour in digging the well was in lieu of payment for their work. It is considered that the Indians, instead of obtaining relief supplies, should, when the opportunity is offered, perform labour. The providing of relief supplies for the labour in digging the well is in the nature of payment for their services, and no extra remuneration will be allowed other than the relief supplies to the amount of $1.50 per day. If the Indians refuse to perform the labour in digging the well on these terms, you should strike their names off the relief list and furnish them with no further supplies.

If any lumber will be required for boxing purposes, you may purchase same from a firm on the list to receive consideration. As instructed in official letter of the 20th ultimo, the well should be properly stoned and a pump and other equipment installed. All costs should be kept as low as possible, and you will see that the Indians engaged do a fair day's work in the digging of the well.

The account covering the cost of the supplies furnished the Indians who do the work should be forwarded as requested in official letter above referred to.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 12th inst., in reference to the digging of a well at Chenail Indian Day School I beg to say that I visited Indians of the Chenail who are on relief at present and who want work, namely, Mitchell Lazere, John Sunday and Frank Sunday.

Sir,

With further reference to the digging of a well at Chenail Indian Day School, I beg to advise that the men commenced work on the 8th of September.

I visited the school on the 22nd inst. The well was 20 ft. deep, with very little water coming in.

This morning the 23rd inst. Frank Sunday, one of the workmen called at my office and said that they had struck water this morning. That there was ten feet of water in the well, and that a number of Indians of the Chenail assisted them in taking water from the well, so that stoning could commence, but that it was impossible to lower the water at all.

A box 4 ft. by 4 ft. and about eight feet high is being sunk at the bottom of the well, so that stoning can be done.

Sir.—

File No. 33-1-5
Chenail School Well.

I beg to say that the digging and stoning of Chenail Day School well has been completed. The workmen were engaged in the work twenty days. Three men, Mitchell Lazere, John Sunday and Frank Sunday. During the work of stoning of the well, there were many other Indians assisted.

The cost of provisions for this work amounted to $30.00.

Some lumber was purchased, I have not received bills for the lumber yet, also one shovel and 23 feet of flexible steel cable. The cable used on this job was borrowed from J. L. Thompson, Indian of St. Regis, but was not long enough after the diggers got to a depth of 26 ft.

The pump for this well was delivered to St. Regis on the 4th inst., purchased from Harold Henry, of Huntingdon, Que. The placing of the pump in this well will be done shortly.

I think this well will be a good one, as a good vein was struck at 31½ ft.

Sir:

Dear Sir:

Re school books

I have received your letter in regard to books etc supplied for use Chenail Indian Day school for the purpose of teaching one of the pupils First Form High school work.

The books were purchased following a conversation with Miss Ursula Billings the teacher in charge of the school. I was advised that the teacher had spoken with Mr. Phelan, Chief, Training Division (by phone), regarding high school training for a Miss McDonald, one of her pupils. It seems Miss Billings received authority to purchase school supplies to the value of $8.00 to $10.00 with the understanding that the pupil would be taught in the local school.

No doubt I should have accompanied the voucher with a letter to the above effect which may have been instrumental in recalling above mentioned conversation to mind.

I find it necessary to forward a requisition for a replacement of the pump at the Chenail Indian Day school, well used also by Indians of the district.

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of the 12th., ultimo, concerning the School Inspector's comment on the condition of some of the desks at the Chenail School, I would advise as follows.

There are two double desks that could be repaired with very little expense. Repairs constitute a few hours of labour and some screw nails. The remainder of the desks that I think the Inspector has reference to are beyond repairs.

I think the most practical way, if it is the desire of the Branch not to expend much money on this school, would be to transfer some of the double desks from the Junior Room of the Village school and purchase new desks to replace the same, thus gradually getting all single desks in this school. To do this we would need two fronts and two backs and twelve single desks No. 4, as manufactured by the Globe Ftr. Co of Waterloo.

While it is granted by doing this we would run to some expense we would nevertheless be bringing the Village school up to some measure of uniformity insofar as desks are concerned. At the same time we would be in a position to settle the seating problem at the Chenail school, where all desks are doubles.

I need not impress upon you the desirability, from a teaching standpoint, especially in the Village School, of having the pupils seated singly. I trust you will see fit to treat the enclosed requisition with the greatest of consideration.

Extract from Inspector Thibault's report on the St. Regis Agency dated May 19, 1942:

I visited the Chenail school. Repairs to the building are greatly needed as well as the rebuilding of both toilets and coal shed; an amount has been placed in the estimates to be used for school buildings repairs, and I think that there will be sufficient to do the most urgent repairs to this school and possible minor repairs to other schools.
Ottawa,
May 21, 1942.

EXD

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his recent visit to the St. Regis Agency, Inspector Thibault recommends the erection of two new toilets at the Chenail School. He also states that the shed requires repairs.

In the current year's appropriation an amount of $500.00 was provided for repairs and improvements at all the schools in your Agency and, in discussing the need for repairs at the Chenail School, Mr. Thibault considered that if approximately $300.00 were spent at Chenail it could be placed in reasonably good condition. This amount, of course, would include the cost of the two new toilets.

Please give this matter your immediate consideration and forward a requisition for the material that you require. At the same time you should state if Indian labour can be secured or if it will be necessary to employ white men.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. D.F. McNaughton,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.
Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of May 21, concerning repairs required at the Chenail Indian Day School, St. Regis Agency, please find attached requisition covering materials needed to make the necessary repairs as well as the construction of toilets at this school.

Materials required can be supplied by the firm of Hodgins Lumber Co., of Cornwall Ontario at a price of $196.59. This price covers materials supplied of good quality.

The labour question has given us some concern as at the present time we have not an Indian on the Reserve capable of doing the work properly. After due consideration the above firm has been approached with a view of supplying the labour as well as materials. A price on the labour has been quoted at $130.00. However this can be reduced to a great extent by us supplying means of transportation for the carpenters from Cornwall to St. Regis via boat, thus reducing cost for bridge toll, passports, etc. A final price arrived for the labour supplied by Hodgins is $95.00 which along with $196.59 for materials gives a total cost for the job by this firm for the amount of $291.59. This price of course does not cover the labour cost of any painting involved but on that item Indian labour can be hired. Some stone will be required for foundation repairs but this item should not exceed $10.00, total cost involved.

In view of the circumstances involved I would strongly recommend that the above firm be permitted to go ahead with the work without delay as we feel confident that not only will good quality materials be supplied but good workmanship performed as well.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir:

In view of the fact that we have only approximately $90.00 of a balance unexpended from the $500.00 allotted for school repairs at this Agency, I write with a view in mind of placing the Chenail Day School in a somewhat better condition from a standpoint of cleanliness and appearance. At this writing there seems little hope that this school will be replaced by a better building for some time to come and it is felt that a paint job inside as well as outside would give the building a much better appearance to stand for at least a few years longer. While the labour is only an estimate you will observe that the estimate for this item as well as materials required will exceed the amount we have left to spend on schools. Mr. R. A. Hoey, Supt. Welfare & Training

In our letter of October 18, we requested a visit from Mr. Ducet at his earliest convenience, with regard to conditions at the Chenail School. Your reply of October 19 advises that he was away at that time, and you would take up the matter with him at his return.

Would you please request Mr. Ducet to bring with him, when he comes, complete information regarding the badge system which he has instituted for use in Indian schools. At the present time, only one school on this reserve—the Cornwall Ild. E. School—is using this system, and that only in a limited form. We are contemplating trying to weave it in with the program of "Indian Scout" club now being organized in the Village.

We had the opportunity to obtain single desks which Father Jacobs had bought with the old Mohawk School and which he was willing to dispose of. We thought it was better to use these than to buy new desks and put them in such a school. The used desks just installed are in good condition and will serve the need until the present school problem in that district can be settled—which it is hoped can be accomplished in the near future.

Further to your letter of July 23rd, File 33-1-5 (W.T. 1), please note the following concerning the proposed two-room school in the Chemall.

I can get Mr. L. Givogue of 25 Belmont Street, Cornwall, to put this school up. He will supervise the construction himself at $1.50 per hour and will hire key carpenters himself at $1.30 per hour plus $2.00 a day to cover bridge toll, etc. We would have to supply the balance of labour and also hunt up materials. He would have to know, of course, at least three or four weeks ahead and that would mean within the next few days if we want construction to start by the middle of September.

Another alternative is the Farley Construction Company of Ottawa. This firm has under construction a large school in the city of Cornwall, and will, while in the vicinity, probably have other jobs to do. In conversation with the representative of this firm the other day, I am advised that they are prepared to take over the job of supplying materials and complete construction. Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Chenaill Indian Day School

Included in our 1947-48 Estimates is a sum for the construction of a new two-room day school at Chenaill in the St. Regis Agency. The attached letter has been received from Mr. Indian Agent Bonnah, after he interviewed all possible construction firms with regard to the building of this school.

We have now received five tenders from the A. E. Farley Construction Company, as follows:

(a) Construction of school on COST PLUS basis, with Concrete block basement.

(b) Construction of school on BULK TENDER price of $27,186.00 with concrete block basement.

(c) Construction of school on COST PLUS basis but with full cement basement as per specifications.

(d) Construction of school on BULK TENDER price of $29,196.00 but with full cement basement according to specifications.

(e) Tender for electrical wiring at a price of $830.00 and installation of plumbing at a price of $2,870.00.

Our Superintendent of Welfare and Training discussed these tenders with Mr. Back of our Surveys and Engineering Branch. Both are agreed that because of the

..... fact
fact that the basement of this school will be used for teaching purposes, a full cement basement should be provided and that the cement blocks will not be satisfactory in this instance. If their recommendation is accepted, then tenders (a) and (b) above are eliminated.

Our experience with the construction of the school on the St. Clair Indian Reserve at Sarnia has led us to the decision that the acceptance of a bulk tender contract is preferable to the acceptance of a Cost Plus Fixed Fee tender. If this recommendation is accepted, it will eliminate tender (c) above and will leave only tender (d) acceptable.

Therefore we would recommend your approval for our preparation of an Order in Council awarding this contract to the Farley Construction Company on the following basis:

(a) Construction of school building according to plans and specifications - $29,196.
(b) Wiring of building - - - 830.
(c) Installation of plumbing - - - 2,670.

$32,896.

Endl.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary and funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a two-room Indian day school in the St. Regis Indian Agency in the Province of Quebec,

THAT it is essential that educational facilities should be provided for Indian children in the St. Regis Indian Agency,

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 186, R.S.C., 1927, provides, in part, as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any department of the Government the Minister having charge of such department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ............";

THAT efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors near the said St. Regis Indian Agency;

THAT a competent constructing firm - A. E. Farley Construction Company, Limited, 30 Russell Avenue, Ottawa, Ontario, - have agreed to undertake the construction of the said building for $32,596.00;

THAT it is considered that the construction of this building is a pressing emergency and it is within the exception of Section 36 above recited.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the construction of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building may be available for use in the near future.

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.

This left us with only my road crew. In order that construction might proceed insofar as the school is concerned, I turned over my road crew to the construction Company. SUBJECT: Care of Stoves and Furnaces.

The Department is quite often put to the unnecessary expense of replacing stove and furnace grates, fire pots and heat radiators in hot air furnaces.

It is understandable that fire pots will burn out and occasionally grates will have to be replaced. Generally speaking, grates would not need replacing if teachers would see to it that ash pans are kept clear. There is little excuse for a radiator in a hot air furnace burning out. The only reason for this is that the teachers or janitors are putting too much in the furnace in the hope that the fire will hold over the week-end or the like. More coal should not be put into any coal burning stove or furnace in excess of what the firepot will hold. Any furnaces or stoves having water pans or water tanks should be checked daily to see that water is at the proper level. In hot air furnaces, it is imperative that water pans be kept filled.

Under separate cover I am mailing you two bottles for use in testing the water at the Chenail Indian Day School well.

To prepare the well for sampling it is necessary to take one quarter (¼) lb. chloride of lime and stir it well into a pailful of water. Stir well and allow the sediment to settle. Then pour the clear water into the well and allow 24 hours to pass. Then pump the well out and allow it to fill again. Two days later, take the two samples in the bottles which we are sending.

The reason for the above procedure is that any well which has been freshly dug is bound to be contaminated during digging and it is necessary to clear the well out before an accurate sample can be taken.

Ottawa, December 20, 1947.

Mr. T.L. Bonnah, Indian Agent, P.O. Box 987, Cornwall, Ont.,

Water Supply - Chenail Indian Day School.

A meeting was held in my office yesterday to discuss the problem of providing an adequate water supply for the above school now being constructed in your agency. We have now received a Bacteriological report on the two samples of water taken from the well which has recently been dug at the school. In both these reports the water has been classified as "D".

Present at the meeting were Mr. Farley, Mr. Buck, Mr. Rankin, Mr. Hargreaves, Mr. Doucet and myself. It was decided that in view of the small supply of water from the present well that two alternatives presented themselves:

(1) To drill a well to a depth of 100 to 125 feet.

(2) To pump water from the St. Lawrence river through a chlorinator into a tank in the school building.

After a long discussion it was unanimously decided to follow course two and be assured of a steady source of water. In view of recent experiences with wells in your agency and because of the heavy expenditure and uncertainty involved in sinking another well, I think you will agree with this solution.

Steps are being taken by our Engineer to prepare the necessary specifications for this project. Mr. Farley will take the necessary soundings and will be prepared to carry out this work as a sub-contract to his main contract. It was decided that we should find out definitely from you as to the possibility of getting power to the school. You will
recall that you had previously mentioned this in past correspondence. It would greatly facilitate the pumping of water from the river to the school if we could arrange for an electric pump rather than a gasoline pump. Therefore, we would appreciate hearing from you as soon as possible regarding recent developments with regard to the provision of power at this school.

Bernard F. Nesry,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Referring to your letter of the 20th, your file 33-1-5 (W.T.) re water supply at the new Chenail School.

It is surprising to learn that the Bacteriological report shows the water to be in Class "D". I think it would be wise to follow the course discussed in your office and have the water brought to the school from the river using a chlorinator.

Regarding the electricity, I wish I could tell you definitely when the power can be brought on the Reserve. The Congress of the United States has already been petitioned to permit the Central New York Power Company to export power to St. Regis Reserve. I was discussing this matter on the telephone with Mr. Woods, the Manager of the Central New York Power Company, the other day but apparently the only thing we can do is wait until the authorization comes through. Mr. Woods did not seem to feel that his Company would not get the permit to export. When the permit is issued, the matter of bringing power onto the Reserve will then be handled through the Shawinigan Power Company. I was speaking to Mr. Mather, the Manager of this Company in Montreal, and according to his information they will be glad to proceed with the work as soon as the Export Permit is issued.

I think we should proceed on the assumption that we will get the power but if the water is required before we have a hook-up with the power, then it is suggested that a gas engine be used in the meantime.

As previously discussed with Mr. Phelan, I would suggest that you telephone Mr. Mather at Lancaster 6281, Montreal.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Phoned Mr. Mather, Shawinigan Power Company, Montreal this morning and he informs me that the possibility of obtaining electricity on the St. Regis Reserve is not very encouraging at the present time.

The situation is that the Shawinigan Power Company is dealing with the United States Electric Company at Hogansburg in an endeavour to obtain electricity from them. If they are successful in this regard they will run a line through the St. Regis Reserve and we can obtain the current required for the Chensil School.

According to Mr. Mathers the American Company is experiencing some difficulty in obtaining permission from the United States to export electricity. However, Mr. Mathers states that the Shawinigan Power Company is extremely anxious to bring a line in and will again take up the matter with the American Company with a view to ascertaining if anything can be done to rush the matter.

Attention Mr. B.F. Neary

Re: St. Regis Indian Agency,
Two Classroom Indian Day School,
Chenail, Que.

Water Supply

In providing a potable water supply for the above school from the St. Regis Channel, we feel that a thorough investigation should be carried out and in addition to the report which shows a colon bacilli count requiring sterilization, it is considered advisable that an analysis of the constitution of the water be made. Such an analysis would show, in parts per million, the total solids, ignition loss, hardness, (as calcium carbonate), sulphates, chlorides, alkalinity, iron, colour, organic matter, etcetera.

It is desirable that this information be supplied so that if any objectionable features are discovered in the supply, they may be studied and such treatment as is found necessary be provided to eliminate same as far as is possible.

The lack of such a standard analysis has not been allowed to interfere with providing you with a sterilized supply of water for the school, but without such an analysis, this Division has no basis on which to comment should such objectionable features eventually occur.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Re: Water Supply - Chenail Indian Day School, St. Regis, Quebec.

In the first paragraph of your letter of January 26th, you state that I recommended that water be taken from the St. Lawrence River and chlorinated for use in the above school. I made no such recommendation. I did recommend that every effort be made to obtain a suitable supply from a shore source and stated that if it were necessary to draw water from the river careful chlorination would be required as I believed the river there was heavily polluted. This belief was verified later by sampling.

With regard to mineral and chemical analysis of the water this can be arranged for you by this Division if you will supply approximately one gallon of the water in question. However, your Engineering and Construction Division need not be unduly perturbed about the physical and chemical quality of the water as there are several municipalities above and below that location which are using the river water with chlorination only.

Re: Heating system - New Chenail School

As you know, considerable effort has been made in order to obtain a hot water heating system for the above school but without avail. While it appeared to the writer that the installation of a hot air heating system would leave little room in the furnace room, I hesitated to make any comment until I could have something definite to work on. When speaking to Mr. Marleau this morning about this matter, he advised me that when the hot air and cold air pipes were attached to the furnace there would definitely be no passageway open between what is shown on the basement plan as the sewing room and manual training room. I also learn from Mr. Marleau that there is no possible way of moving this furnace around to arrange a passageway between the two rooms.

I am advising you of the above in the event that the Engineering Service might have some plan whereby the passageway they have shown on the plan between these two rooms can be utilized.

It is most unfortunate that in putting up a building of this nature the hot water heating system was not provided for. It appears to the writer that the cost of construction of this building warrants something better than a hot air heating system.

Dear Sir,

"RE CHENAIL INDIAN DAY SCHOOL"
ST. REGIS RESERVE

Immediately after the award to us of Contract to build the above school, the important matter of obtaining a Safe Domestic Water supply was investigated and it was concluded that sufficient good water would be found if a Well was excavated or dug, close to the building. It was thought that water would be secured at an approx. depth of 15 feet.

We were instructed to proceed with this undertaking and work was started at same on October 6th and was carried on until December 13th, when work was abandoned, after Well had been excavated to a depth of 32 feet. The water supply secured at this depth was not sufficient for requirements and after Tests of water had been made by the Department, the water at this level was found to be absolutely Unsafe for domestic purposes.

The cost of work on Well to December 13th amounts to the sum of $1151.00.

It is now found necessary to obtain and use water from the St. Lawrence River channel but this water is not safe for Domestic purposes and must be Chlorinated.

To supply and Install Jet type centrifugal water pump powered by means of a belt driven to a Briggs & Stratton Gasoline engine and equipped with a pressure switch which will shut the engine down when proper pressure has been built up in the Tank, also Chlor-O-Feeder equipped with two 5 gallon solution tanks and belt driven from the engine so as whenever the engine is operating sterilized solution will be applied to pump suction. Further it will be necessary to increase size of Electric service entering building from 30 amperes to 60 amperes to permit of the supply and installation of a 30 gallon Hot water tank with 3000 watt heater and also provide wiring for pump when power is supplied to the building.

The estimated cost of this work amounts to $1200.00
To secure water from St. Lawrence, it will be necessary to provide and lay a 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" galvanized pipe line from Pump room to St. Lawrence river, allowing said pipe to extend far enough into the River to permit obtaining an adequate water supply at all times. The River end of the pipe will have to be approximately Six feet below water level to prevent damage from Ice formation and pipe line leading to building to be 6'6" below grade to prevent same from freezing. The work involves all excavation, sheeting of trench and unwatering required to complete this work.

The estimated cost of this work amounts to $1700.00

Trusting the above will meet with your requirements and awaiting your valued instructions.

Following his recent visit to the above, Mr. Buck noted two items in connection with the gravity warm air furnace which are hereby brought to your attention.

Item 2 - No shaker was noticed, and as far as can be seen it appeared that the grates were stationary.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Chensil Indian Day School - Water Supply.

Mr. Jackson's memorandum of March 25 has been noted.

When the actual site of the school was being decided upon, Mr. Rankin of the Lands and Development Services, Mr. Phelan of our Education Division and Mr. Indian Agent Bonnah thoroughly inspected several alternative locations, all of which were satisfactory. We were not able to buy the site selected as the Indian was not willing to sell. However, the alternative site upon which the school has been built, is actually closer to the St. Lawrence River than the original location. On the basis of depths to which wells had been dug on adjacent properties, it appeared that well water should be reached at a depth of approximately 15 feet. The Indian home next to the school had a well of this depth with an ample supply of water (see attached photograph 1).

The school is located less than 150 feet from the St. Lawrence (at this point about 35 feet deep and flowing at approximately 7 miles per hour). When the contractor reported lack of water at this depth in the well, we wrote on October 25, 1947, to the Public Health Engineering Division of the Department of National Health and Welfare. We asked that they test the river water at this point to ascertain if it were fit for public consumption. Their engineer visited the site on November 6 and took samples of the river water. The report on this water showed it as unfit for public consumption.

Therefore we consulted the engineers of the Lands and Development Services Branch and it was decided to deepen the well...
to 32 feet in the hope that water would be found at that level. At this point there was a slow water flow. Two bottles of the water from the well were tested and found unfit for public consumption ("D").

On December 19 a meeting was held in the office of the Superintendent of Education to discuss the water supply for this school. Present at this meeting were Messrs. Buck, Rankin, Hargreaves of Lands and Development Services Branch; Mr. Farley, the contractor; and Messrs. Neary, Phelan and Doucet of this Branch. It was decided, in view of the small supply of water from the dug well, that two alternatives presented themselves:

(1) To drill a well to a depth of 100 to 125 feet.

(2) To pump water from the St. Lawrence River through a chlorinator into a tank in the school building.

After a long discussion it was unanimously decided to follow course 2 and thus be assured of a non-failing source of water. In view of the heavy expenditure and uncertainty involved in the sinking of another well, it is felt that this was a proper solution.

Therefore the engineers took action to prepare the necessary specifications for this project. When the specifications were prepared, Mr. Farley was asked to tender on them as a subcontract to his main contract. His tender was as follows:

(a) Installation of water pump, electric water heater, solution tanks, etc. ........................................ $1,200.00

(this amount can be reduced by the installation of an oil kitchen range with coils for heating water).

(b) Excavation, sheeting of trench, laying of 1½ inch galvanized pipeline to river, anchoring same against current and winter ice, etc. ........................................ $1,700.00

It must be realized that items covered by (a) above are features which would be required, regardless of the source of water supply, and therefore must be considered as part of the building rather than to be associated with (b) which involves
only water delivery from the source. Confirming the costs quoted please find attached both Mr. Farley's tender and a memorandum from Mr. Mills advising that the prices are fair and reasonable.

Messrs. Buck and Neary inspected this school last week and final payment on the main contract has been authorized. With the exception of one or two details for which the contractor admits responsibility, they found the work entirely satisfactory. The water situation was carefully reviewed and it is recommended that authority be given for the letting of the sub-contract and the payment of the original well account as previously submitted. It is emphasized that this is a completely modern school for some sixty or seventy children with good living accommodation for two teachers. Flush toilets and wash basins are installed as authorized by Order-in-Council and it is essential that a guaranteed source of water be assured. In view of past experiences by this Branch in attempting to make use of an uncertain water supply, we hope to follow in future the policy of getting water from an assured source. Initially the cost may be higher but in the long run we save money by eliminating continuous minor expenses due to well failures. It is therefore requested that the Minister approve the payment of the account for the old well and the letting of the two sub-contracts to the Farley Construction Company.

Immediately after the award to us of Contract to build the above School, the important matter of obtaining a Safe Domestic Water Supply was investigated and it was concluded that sufficient good water would be found if a Well was excavated or dug close to the building. It was thought that water would be secured at an approximate depth of 15 feet.

We were instructed to proceed with this undertaking and work was started on same on October 6th and was carried on until December 13th, when work was abandoned, after Well had been excavated to a depth of 32 feet. The water supply secured at this depth was not sufficient for requirements and after Tests of water had been made by the Department, the water at this level was found to be absolutely Unsafe for domestic purposes.

The cost of work on Well to December 13th amounts to the sum of $1,151.00.

It is now found necessary to obtain and use water from the St.Lawrence River channel but this water is not safe for Domestic purposes and must be Chlorinated.

To supply and Install Jet type centrifugal water pump powered by means of a belt driven to a Briggs & Stratton Gasolene engine or equivalent motor power and equipped with a pressure switch which will shut the engine down when proper pressure has been built up in the Tank, also Chlor-O-Feeder equipped with two 5 gallon solution tanks and belt driven from the engine so as whenever the engine is operating sterilized solution will be applied to pump suction. Further it will be necessary to increase size of Electric service entering building.

from 30 amperes to 60 amperes to permit of the supply and installation of a 30 gallon Hot Water Tank with 3000 watt heater and also provide wiring for pump when power is supplied to the building.

Ottawa, May 6, 1948.

Re: Heating System, Chenail Indian Day School, St. Regis Reserve, Province of Quebec.

With reference to Col. Neary's memorandum of May 3rd, bearing your notation of the 4th inst., in connection with the above, it is felt that the following suggestion should be brought to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch.

We have been advised by the General Steel Wares that their Number 4170 and 4190 Magnet Furnaces, which are being supplied for a number of Two-Classroom Schools, could be fitted with suitable linings and grates for burning coal.

Following a recent inspection at the above, Mr. Buck pointed out that in his opinion the grates and linings were not suitable for coal burning and that no means of shaking the grates were provided; also that the ash pit was very shallow.

Since several schools of the above type are to be built, it is felt that in those areas where coal is to be burnt, the manufacturer should be contacted before the furnaces are ordered and advised specifically, in order that proper linings and grates with suitable shaker may be supplied.

ATTENTION: Mr. B. F. Neary.

As previously advised, it was our intention to transfer the gas operated pump from the Sisters' Residence to the new Chenail School. However, it does not appear that we will have the power connected in St. Regis Village until perhaps late in September. This means we can not move the gas pump from the Sisters' Residence.

Would you give me authority to purchase a gas operated shallow well pump for the new Chenail School which we will have installed there? It is not my intention to remove the electric pump now installed. Mr. Gendron, at my request, visited the Shawinigan Power office in Montreal and I learned from him that we would not be able to get the power in the Chenail this Fall. After considering the distance the Power Company will have to come to maintain our lines here, it might be advisable to purchase a gas engine now, install it, and leave it there after the power is hooked up as an auxiliary unit. This would protect us in the event of the lines being down for a long period such as we encountered with the telephone here during the sleet storm a few winters ago. If you can purchase a gas operated shallow well pump in Ottawa, it might be advisable to do so and have it sent here right away.

Your early reply, please.

T. L. Bonnah,
Superintendent,
