ATTENTION: Mr. B. F. Neary.

Concerning our telephone discussion about the water system at the new Chenail School, please be advised that I am returning the pump to Eaton's which was purchased at a cost of $89.50. As advised, this pump, not having an air vent, is not suitable for a pressure system.

To serve our needs at the school, I purchased, locally, a new 1½ h.p. gas engine which was on a milking machine at the local Massey-Harris. There was an old pump at the Agency which was discarded some 10 years ago and which we have been able to put into shape for pumping. This unit is not, by any means, modern but it has an air vent and, together with the new engine, is supplying water to our new school. There will be, undoubtedly, a few more adjustments and possibly a little expenditure in this connection but it is expected the cost will not be very high. The cost of the new engine is around $65.00 which, together with the pump installation, will hardly exceed the cost of the pump purchased from Eaton's.

ATTENTION: Mr. B. F. Neary

Re: Furnace - New Chenail School.

It was my understanding when Mr. Buck and yourself were here that we would have a shaker grate installed in the furnace of the above school. The grate has been installed and the side castings. It is a permanent grate. I am somewhat dubious about the satisfaction we will get from this furnace. I am not against a permanent grate but I am quite sure that with a casting of not more than ten inches high set on the grate on both sides and the end that we will not get very much satisfaction. In the first place, there is no way to bank a fire. Consequently, with a fire box of that size, side castings won't last two months. While it is my opinion that the side walls and back of this furnace should be bricked with fire brick, there does not seem to be any way we can get this done unless we undertake to do it ourselves. It appears that insofar as the Company is concerned, they just sent one permanent grate and four side castings not over ten inches high along with one casting of similar height for the back. While I have had some changes made from the original installation made by the subcontractor, Marleau, I am certainly not satisfied as yet.

Perhaps Mr. Buck or the Company concerned might be able to supply further information.

Apropos discussion and letter of September 15th concerning the furnace in the new Chenail School, when Mr. Buck, Mr. Neary, Mr. Farley and the writer were discussing the type of grates to be used in the furnace, it was definitely understood, at the school that day, that we would be getting a shaker grate so that we could burn hard coal. At that time, your office was pressing for information in order to requisition fuel for the schools but my reply of June 16th last was held up pending information as noted above.

As shown in my letter of the 15th instant, the grates arrived and were installed in the furnace. Being somewhat dubious, I wrote you explaining the situation. In the meantime, I discussed the matter thoroughly with Mr. Ryan of the Farley Construction Company as it appeared to the writer that the grates as installed would definitely not give us satisfaction burning hard coal. In an endeavour to help us, Mr. Ryan arranged for two officials of the General Steel Wares to come here and look this furnace over. Mr. Hebert and another official of the General Steel Wares in Montreal came here yesterday and, after looking the furnace over, stated definitely that we would never get any satisfaction by burning hard coal in the furnace.
These officials produced all correspondence from the Engineering Branch and it appears that no mention ever was made to the Company for anything else but a wood or soft coal burning unit. It is common knowledge that in this location wood is very difficult to obtain and soft coal is no substitute in a hot air heating system in a school. The officials of General Steel Wares, when questioned as to the practicability of burning soft coal in our school, even if some could be obtained, said they certainly would not recommend it under such conditions. This, of course, is quite understandable.

I understand that the type of furnace that should be installed there is a G.S.W. 20-36 Heavy Duty Warm Air Furnace, specially built for hard coal, coke or wood, equipped with shaker grates and deep ash pit. It is my understanding that such a unit could be installed in place of the present one. The officials could not tell me whether such a unit was available but, undoubtedly, information can be had on this point from the Toronto head Office of this firm.

According to information from the Engineering Branch to G.S.W., a wood burning unit will be used in many schools now under construction or to be constructed in the near future. It would seem advisable, therefore, to obtain, if possible, the 20-36 unit and install it here and have the present unit sent to some school where wood is obtainable. As to installation of the shaker unit, this should not present such a great problem as both models are similar and very little alteration would have to be made to the heating jacket.

T. L. Bonnah,
Superintendent,
St. Regis Agency.

In the meantime I will try and see present furnace although grate and combustion chamber are not for type of fuel using.

Attention - Mr. R.F. Neary

Further to our telephone conversation of even date re roof Chensil School please note that due to heavy wind Thursday night and Friday last some damage was done. While it is difficult to ascertain at this writing the amount of damage done by winds some of the asphalt shingles on the northwest roof of the building have become completely loosened from the nails. Arrangements have been made to have these replaced without delay. Mr. Ryan of Farley Constr. Co., has agreed to take his men to the school Monday for repairs.

What I am concerned about is that we are going to have continuous trouble every time we get a high wind unless we either put an asbestos roof on the west side of the school and residence or are able to cement down the present shingles. I understand that unless we get very warm weather cement will not prove out very successful. The greatest trouble is going to be in finding out just what shingles are lifting from the nails as it would appear that without renailing we would not get the full use or benefit even if the shingles were cemented. While the visible amount of damage is, at present, slight it is hard to say how many shingles are lifting from the nails and to learn this practically every shingle will have to be lifted from the flap or weather end. Such a procedure does not help a roof of this nature. While talking to an experienced roofing man this morning I learn that such a roof, while giving long service in a town or city or well sheltered community, is not practical in open country especially so when the roof surface is large.

T.E. Bonnah
Supt.: St.Regis Agcy.

Referring to your letter of November 18th last, file 306-5 (R.5), please be advised that the old Chenail School is located on Lot 109 as shown on Quebec Plan 3026. While the survey of this section of the Chenail is comparatively recent, I might say that, at one time, Lots 108 and 109 were together. Lot 108 is still in the Skitters family.

As far as I am able to learn, it would seem that the above property has been owned by Joe Skitters for many years. Some of the older Councillors tell me that Joe lived on this property for at least the last 25 years or more. When I questioned Joe about the small parcel upon which the school was built, he told me that the Department paid $25.00. I do not seem to be able to locate any correspondence in the office here and Joe is unable to give me information as to when the transaction transpired. Possibly your records in Ottawa may throw some light on the subject.

As far as not being able to find information concerning any land located to Mr. Skitters, I might remind you that it is only very recently that it was possible to have the Council agree to the Location Ticket system at this Agency.

Perhaps with the above information we might be now in a position to proceed with the disposition of this very old building and also the small lot.

With reference to your letter of December 16th last, your file 306-5 (E), and further to copy of our letter to A.E. Farley Construction Company, December 20th, please be advised that the damaged shingles on the section of the Chenail School roof facing the north west were repaired.

However, during the high wind storm yesterday and last night, this portion of the roof received considerable damage with the result that many shingles are loosened and some blown off. It would appear that no matter what procedure we adopt with that type of asphalt shingles, we are not going to get satisfaction and whether or not we can recall the contractor to repair the recent damage is not clear to the writer. The recent high winds caused considerable damage in various sections of the Province and it is a debatable point as to whether we can hold the contractor liable to repairs in this case. Only the side of the roof and residence where the shingles were lifting at the time of Mr. Buck's visit appear to receive any damage during wind storms. If we can not hold the contractor liable, there would appear to be only one thing we can do and that is nail the shingles down on the flap and, in the Spring, put on a similar roofing on this part of the building to what was put on the Agency Residence.

I shall be pleased to await your directions before taking further action.

T. L. Bonnah,
Superintendent,
St. Regis Agency.

Re: Your file 306-5 (R.5), January 17th, 1949.

With reference to the above noted, please be advised that there must be some mistake as I can find no evidence of such a party as Joe Lazore ever having anything whatsoever to do with the lot on which the old Chenail School stands. There seems no doubt that Lots 108 and 109 have been in the Skitters family for many years.

I have been able to unearth information to the effect that the exact site where the school is located was not purchased by the Department but Joe Skitters' grandfather apparently permitted the Department to build the school on that spot. With regard to the small parcel for which $25.00 was paid, it appears that the Department was anxious to get enough land where the children could have a small playground near the school and also that fuel could be brought in and placed in the small lean-to at the back of the school. Undoubtedly, that is the agreement that was made October 1st, 1929. The small parcel in question extends from the school for the depth of the lot to where the present boundary line is shown between Lots 108 and 109. How the name Joe Lazore enters into the picture, I do not know, but it was quite likely a mistake on the part of whoever wrote the agreement.
Under the circumstances, and in fairness to Mr. Skitters, I don't think we have any other alternative but to give him an opportunity of getting this small parcel back and also that portion which was given by his grandfather as the original school site and which, at one time, formed part of Lots 108 and 109.

[Signature]

Concerning the Old Chenail School Site on Lot 108 your attention is drawn to your letter of February 1st your file 6-242 in which you point out that from all the information you could gather you cannot determine who was Joe Lazore who signed an agreement with His Majesty on October 1st, 1929, selling a parcel of land for school purposes in the amount of $25.00.

We are attaching for your information one copy of the agreement which we have on file. Will you kindly peruse these and make a further check as to the whereabouts of Joe Lazore.

It now appears from your letter that the parcel of land which Joe Skitters requests that it be returned to him is not the parcel that was purchased by the Department but the land given for school purposes by his grandfather. In view of this we are questioning what about this parcel which was purchased for $25.00 from Joe Lazore? Will you please make a further investigation and reply returning the copy of the agreement.

I wish to refer to your letter of February 17th, your file 306-5 (R.5), re Lot 108, old school site in the Chenail.

In the above connection, I am returning herewith the copy of agreement which you sent here. You will also find attached a Statutory Declaration made by Joe Skeeters which may, in your estimation, have some bearing on the lot in question.

In summing this matter up, I would say there is no doubt in my mind but Joe Skeeters and Joe Lazore is one and the same party. Mr. Skeeters is still under the same Band number (318) that was used to pay interest money on his account back as far as 1914. What Mr. Skeeters wants, and which I think he is justified in asking for, is the return of that parcel of land upon which the Chenail School rests and which was given as a school site free by his grandfather. Also, the opportunity to purchase back, in the amount of $25.00, that parcel of land sold to the Department on October 1st, 1929, lying between the site previously given by his grandfather and Lot 109.

MEMORANDUM TO:

Mr. Phelan, (E.1)

On Lots 108 and 109 there is the Old Chenail School Site on which is located an old school building. Superintendent Bonnah has been corresponding with this office with a view to return the land to the Indian from whom it has been acquired some years ago for school purposes.

This school site involves two different parcels of land acquired at different times. The ½ acre of land on Lot 109 Chenail Range was acquired some years ago and from the information that Superintendent Bonnah gives, this was donated by the grandfather of Joe Skitters. On this one-half acre of land the school was built and from a letter dated October 28th, 1948, Mr. Bonnah suggested that since this school building is of no further use that it be given to Tom Debo who would remove it from the present site and turn it into a residence for himself and family.

The land, he suggested be returned to the present owner. Will you kindly advise us whether this building is of any further use to you and if not are you prepared to recommend that it be turned over to a member of the band so that it may be used as a residence. With regard to the one-half acre of land if you have no further use of it you might also advise us to that effect so that action may be taken in compliance with Mr. Bonnah's suggestion.

.....
With regard to the one-half acre on Lot 108, this was purchased on October 1st, 1929 for $25.00 from Mr. Joe Lazore who now goes under the name of Joe Skitters. This Indian is willing to refund the $25.00 paid for the land. Will you kindly advise whether you have any further use of this one-half acre and whether action may be taken on the suggestion of Mr. Bonnah to return the land to the present owner.

D.J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.

GENERAL REMARKS.

In order to reach all the children of school age, a new school should be erected near Sugarbush Island, perhaps not on the Island but West of it, near the residence of Louis David. I am informed by the Indians that there are over 20 children who do not attend any school as the Chenail school is the nearest one to them and that is too far to attend, being over three miles away. I think the Indians would do better under compulsory educational laws. They are very careless about their children. The Chenail school house only holds 40 children and would not accommodate all the children in the district.

Sgd. A. Luther Gilman

Inspector of Schools
Ottawa, June 19, 1912.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Gilman in his report on the Chenail Indian Day School states that a new school should be erected near Sugarbush Island near the residence of Louis David.

The Department would like you to go fully into the question of the need of a new school. I am sending herewith a blue print of that portion of the reserve and I would ask you to show on it the location of the homes of Indians with children to attend the school and mark on each lot the number of children. I would also ask you to show the dividing line between this proposed section and present Chenail school section. You will notice on this plan that a lot has been reserved for school purposes, but this would not appear to be a central location.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Francis E. Tailon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.
Sir,

Referring to your of Aug. 12, 1912 #408626, I have looked into the matter and have decided that a school is essential for that portion of the reserve. While visiting the location many were anxious to know a school and especially those who are associated now with all people and they are more than eager that a school should be erected. I have marked the place considered to be the most desirable for school location, also the dividing line between the two districts.

I hope I have made the matter quite clear.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Pedley,

After leaving the Tyendinaga Reserve I went to St. Regis and visited all the schools on the reserves. Extensive repairs have been made to each of the schools and they are now in excellent condition.

The new school at Chetlain on the lower Chenail is nearing completion and Mr. Angus Lalonde, the contractor, has made an excellent job of it. The site chosen is high and dry and the school will accommodate all the children in that neighborhood. The building stands on a good solid foundation which has been properly laid and the lumber used is well seasoned and of good quality. The plans and specifications made no provision for closets, but Mr. Lalonde informed me that he would put up two separate closets for $30.00 a piece. This appears to be a reasonable price and I would recommend that his offer be accepted.

The school will be ready for occupation early next month and we have already had an application from Mrs. Cook, an Indian woman, who holds a Model School diploma.
diploma and is very highly spoken of and her appointment would be satisfactory to the Indians. She would be quite willing to live close to the school and, as it would be a difficult matter to get a white teacher as well able to instruct the Indians, I think it would be well to secure her services, if she will accept a salary of $400.00 a year.

The only additional requirement I found needed for the Cornwall Island School were two gates, which could be put in for about $10.00. These were not called for in Mr. Lalonde's arrangement for repairs. The Department has been asked to fence off the school lot, but I think that this might stand till the spring, as there will be very little need of a fence this fall.

The question of fencing the St. Regis Island School could also remain in abeyance.

A pump will be required for the new well at the Village School. They have secured an excellent supply of water there and the well has been cased and should be boarded over when the new pump is placed in position. Mr. Taillon should be authorized to purchase a pump.

None of these schools have been furnished with flags and, as they all lie in the neighborhood of the United States.
States border where the Stars and Stripes are constantly in view, I think it would be well to give them each a nine foot flag and instruct the Agent to have suitable poles provided and fly the flags on all state occasions.

The teacher of the St. Regis Island School sent in her resignation to take effect on the 30th of this month and a new teacher will have to be engaged. It is an isolated place to live in and the accommodation is not very satisfactory, but we have an application from Miss Burke, who has had some year's experience in teaching and is probably the only one we could engage at such short notice. I would recommend that she be employed at the usual salary.

The new teacher has taken charge of the Village School and from what I have since learnt she is likely to give satisfaction. At all events there will be no recurrence of the trouble we had with the late teacher.

Sir,

In regard to crossing from St Regis Village to the Settlement school every day, I fear that this block is not very feasible, as during the school year there are times when it is impossible to cross the river. Sir,

I trust you will pardon the liberty I am taking of addressing this letter to you, but I am very anxious to obtain an Indian school, have applied to different sources but have not been successful so far. I taught at one time in the Bay Cove Indian school in Kent Co., N.B., & had to resign very suddenly owing to the unexpected illness & death of a relative dependent.
I would like to secure a school for the term in some part of Upper Canada or in the Western provinces, as I am an orphan and would like to make it a permanent work. I have lived near an Indian reserve and well fitted to be a teacher of the Indians. I have an Elementary School diploma from the Province of Quebec but had been educated in the High School at Campbellton N.B. I have taught four years in one school in the province, am pretty thoroughly trained in domestic work, any kind of fancy work, sewing, crocheting or needlework, and find myself understand taught in the schools at present can teach French also fairly well. May add when I took charge of the Indian school at Cross Point I found the children had been nearly all trained in the Micmac language by the former teacher, which was their own language. I did my best to form classes and establish order among them, which met with commendation from the Priest who visited the school every month. He took a deep interest in all matters relating to education, and enclosed a copy of reference from him, also a self addressed stamped envelope. If you will kindly lend your aid to help me to secure a position I do not care about the isolation of it, but would like it in one of those places already mentioned, or if you could help me to secure a position as clerk in any of the offices of the Dept., it is needless to say how deeply grateful I shall be, and will do my very best to prove myself worthy of same.

Again asking pardon for my intrusion, praying to hear from you at an early date.

I remain Sir,

P. D. Archibald

Cross Point,
Co. Bonaventure.

Father Ryan, Superintendent of Indian Schools, in a report dated the 30th of November, 1909, stated that "I do not find that the children are getting on as they ought, but am inclined to credit this state of affairs to the fact that under the late teacher, Miss Isaacs, the children spoke in the Indian language mostly and in consequence it is hard for the present teacher to overcome this drawback to their studies". The attendance was unsatisfactory, owing to the lack of interest of the parents, and in consequence of their indifference it was a difficult matter for a teacher to make any headway.

Miss
Miss Archibald would now be about 38 years of age and, if she has been teaching since she left the Big Cove School, she will have gained experience and might meet with better success in another locality. His Excellency

Angus Lalonde, Cornwall, for $2,978.00.

The undersigned would recommend, pursuant to the requirements of subsection 2, of section 36, of the Public Works Act, that the contract be awarded to Mr. Lalonde for the amount of his tender above quoted, it being reported by the Architect of the Department, that this tender is fair and reasonable.

Funds are available from the Vote for Indian Education.

Extract from Inspector's Report on the
CHETLAH SCHOOL. March 14, 1923.

The buildings are in good order except the
storm door to the porch is damaged. Some
of the panes are broken. Also the out-
houses are in poor condition. They are
dirty.

A. L. Gilman,
Insp.
Ottawa, April 4th, 1923.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Chetlain Indian Day School, states that the buildings are in good condition, except that the storm door to the porch is damaged, and some panes of glass are broken. He also states that the out houses are in poor condition and dirty.

You will be good enough to arrange as soon as weather conditions permit to have the storm door to the porch repaired. Any broken panes of glass should be replaced, and the out houses should be put in good condition and thoroughly cleaned. No unnecessary expense should be incurred for this work.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P.Q.
Sir,

During my recent inspection of the Chenail School I found the foundation in need of repairs, the stones have, in many places, become loose, while in others they have fallen out of the walls entirely. I have, therefore, to recommend that authority be given me to have these repairs made by so doing the school will be very much warmer during the cold winter months.

J.D. McLean, Sec.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Agent.
Sir,

While visiting the Chetlain School during the present month, I find that a new covering of the well is required; for this purpose several planks will be necessary.

The storm doors now in use are altogether too light and I have to ask for authority to have two new ones made.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean, Sec.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Agent.
Ottawa, September 29th, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, informing the Department that a new covering is required for the well at the Chetlain Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that you may purchase the planks necessary to renew the covering of this well, and arrange to have the work required carried out. You may also arrange for the purchase of two new storm doors of the dimensions required. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred, and properly certified vouchers should be forwarded covering the cost.

I have also to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the above date, regarding the repairs required to the foundation. You may arrange to have the repairs required carried out. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to see that a satisfactory job is made, and that the foundation is placed in good condition. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded.

The above repairs should receive your early attention in order that they will be completed before the extreme cold weather sets in.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

F. D. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.

Sir:

St. Regis, Island Indian Day School.

The foundation under this school is entirely done. In many places there is no foundation at all. To place this building in shape, a new foundation is required, of stone or cement. I would consider cement the best, and almost as cheap. The building should be raised about fifteen inches from the ground.

I have consulted Mr. Thompson, caretaker of this school, about two weeks ago, with respect to this work. Thompson promised to let me know, but has not to date. I expect due to the river breaking up, and clearing of ice. As to the cost of this work, I would say, that between $70.00 and $80.00 would complete the job. Perhaps Thompson's figure may be lower than that.

This is an old building, but by putting a good foundation under it, the building would serve for some years yet.

As to the paint to be used in redecorating interior of Chetlain school, I wish to say, that I have had considerable trouble in previous painting jobs, by Indians, with respect to mixing paint. To have a good satisfactory job done, at this school, I would recommend ready mixed paint supplied. Although it may be possible, to secure some Indian painter who knew the art of mixing paint correctly.

Some of this school repairing could be done this Spring, previous to the summer school holidays.

Chenail Indian Day School.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, relative to the interior redecorating at the Chatlain Indian Day School, and stating the work required to be carried out and the approximate cost of same, including material and labour.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of having the interior redecorated. The woodwork, walls and ceiling should be thoroughly washed; the ceiling painted white, two coats, and the plaster walls painted buff, two coats, if required, and the washroom and two entrances painted. Ottawa, February 24, 1931.

Sir:

I have to refer to that portion of your report for the month of January, last, on the Chetlain Indian Day School, drawing attention to the condition of the pump. It is noted that the school pump has been put in working condition several times but that, through misuse, it is frequently put out of order. Please state whether it would not be possible to obtain, from a nearby well, the small quantity of water that would be required for drinking purposes at this school. If this could be done, it is considered that the repairing of the school pump could be deferred. You might advise as to the repairs necessary and the approximate cost and also state whether the supply of water required could not be obtained from some well near the school.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to refer you to my letter to you of April 10th, 1930 with reference to redecorating and repairing of schools on St. Regis reserve.

With reference to redecorating interior of Chetlain Indian Day School, you authorized this work to be done in spring 1930 but later, (Refer to your letter of April 29/30) that owing to funds being limited, you cancelled this work.

Chetlain school is badly in need of interior redecorating. At present the class-room has a very backward and neglected appearance.

In event of you approving of this work being done this year, I would recommend that a competent painter be engaged, other than an Indian, as I mentioned before to you, that it is almost impossible to find an Indian who does good interior painting. For outside work, painting, there are a few Indians who do fair work.

St. Regis Village school requires a coat of paint, outside. It's almost four years since this school was painted. St. Regis Island School should be painted, exterior, also the shed at this school, which was newly built in 1929, should be painted.

These outside jobs could be done by Indian of the reserve. Work is very scarce for Indians of St. Regis reserve, and by giving some painting jobs, would help out some families who are in rather close circumstances.

With reference to Chetlain school, if you approve of the interior being redecorated, I would get a price on cost of work, and forward to you for consideration.

Please advise me, if there are funds available to have the work mentioned carried out this year.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I beg to say that Chetlain Indian Day School needs the interior redecorated very badly. The ceiling should be given a thorough cleaning; the walls should be cleaned and given a coat of muresco. Some of the other schools on the reserve need the same.

Nurse Cousins and myself suggest that if the muresco was supplied, which is very cheap, a five pound package for 55 cents, to have some of the Indians who are on relief go ahead and get this work done. Seven or eight Indians would clean the ceiling and walls of one school, and put on the muresco in a day or so.

If you would allow me to purchase say, 20 lbs. muresco, which would cost $2.60 and also two wide brushes, $1.00 each, we would try to get this work done before Christmas. It would take more muresco than above for all the schools, but the total cost of muresco would not exceed $6.00.

I would like to be advised on this question of employing Indians on relief in cleaning the interior of the schools.

Ottawa, December 8, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the first instant, recommending that the interior of the Chetlain Indian Day School be redecorated. It is noted that the ceiling requires a thorough cleaning and the walls should be cleaned and given a coat of muresco.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of approximately 5 lbs. of muresco and two wide brushes. You should arrange with Indians on relief to clean the walls and ceiling and apply the muresco, provided you are satisfied that they could perform satisfactory work. In view of the relief which they receive, it is understood that there will be no charge for the labour. Please obtain an account, in triplicate, covering the cost of the muresco and the brushes. This, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

The Department will be unable to incur the expenditure required in redecorating and cleaning the other schools on the reserve, unless the entire work could be performed by Indians on the relief list, without expense other than for the material. If you consider the Indians could do the work satisfactorily, you may forward a list of the materials required and an estimate of the cost. Consideration will then be given as to whether funds for the purpose can be provided.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Sir:

Ottawa, February 4, 1935.

When Mr. Armstrong visited the St. Regis Reserve recently, it was brought to his attention by Miss G. Lagarde, teacher of the Chetlain Indian Day School, that a Quebec heater is required at that school.

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a suitable stove at a cost not to exceed $18.00. Please give this matter your immediate attention, as Mr. Armstrong understood that the continued use of the present stove is dangerous.

Your obedient servant,

J. H. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Dr. W. R. W. Haight,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.
I have a report from Chetlain School that the No. 2 Quebec heater purchased and sent to them is much too small to heat the school room. It requires at least a No.5 stove of the same type to provide heat for the school room.

I shall visit the hardware store when next in Cornwall and see if I can get another style of stove sufficiently large at the figure you allow for the purchase.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, February 28, 1935.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 18th instant, I beg to say that, from information received by the Department, it is considered that a No. 5 Quebec heater can be secured at a cost not exceeding $18.00.

The Department cannot understand why a No. 2 heater was sent to the Chetlain Indian Day School. It is hoped that this latter stove has not been used. If it has, it may be difficult to get the dealer to take it back. Please give this matter your immediate attention as, apparently, the stove supplied to the school is of very little use.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. R. W. Haight, Esq., M. D.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.
Sir:

With Reference to your letter of 24th ult. re No.5 Quebec Heater for Chetlain Indian Day School, I authorised Miss Legarde to exchange the No.2 purchased from Smith Hardware for a No.5 second hand which was very nearly new. I did this because upon consulting Smith Hardware people I was told a No.5 new would cost another $2 at the least. The stove being urgently needed, I thought it best to make this arrangement in order to save time.

Your Obedient Servant,

W.R.W. Haight, M.D.
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, June 22, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to his inspection of the Chetlain Indian Day School on the 25th ultimo, Inspector Wescott states that the two doors are in need of repair and the door knobs are missing. If the cost involved will be reasonable, you may arrange to have the doors repaired and the door knobs replaced.

The Inspector also states that the toilets require cleaning, especially the boys' toilet. You should arrange to have the toilets properly cleaned before the school reopens in September, and you should see that they are kept clean during the academic year.

Yours truly,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

D. P. McNaughton, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P.Q.
Sir,

I wish to recommend the redecorating of the interior of the Chetlain Indian Day school. The paint has peeled off of a considerable portion of the ceiling and it will require two coatings of paint to make a finished job. The wainscoting will require one coat of paint, applied after a thorough washing, while the plastered walls, which have been muredescoed, will need to be very thoroughly washed if paint is to be applied, but as they are in fair condition I would think they could be put in good shape if muresco was again applied.

Two gallons of paint should be sufficient for the ceiling and two for the wainscoting with 3 boxes of muresco required for the plastered walls. Charlie Seymour will furnish the labour for at not more than $25.00, the brushes and sandpaper, to be supplied.

Water has seeped through the roof, around the chimney, causing the plaster to be broken away, this will require repairing also the roof, around the chimney to prevent rain from entering. There is some small repairing to be done to the south porch, a plank in the steps to be replaced. This is included in the labour cost.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:-

With reference to the enclosed voucher No.246, for $2.10 in favor of Mrs Annie Peters for cleaning of Chetlain school and Teacher's residence.

Mrs Annie David who had advised that she would renovate the rooms occupied by the teacher did not make much of a job of it. I had Mrs Peters scrub the floor of the school and clean the windows, following which she scrubbed the floor cleaned the windows and woodwork of the teachers quarters.

Respecting the residence, Miss Foisey has advised me that she has found bugs which have come through from the other part of the dwelling. I supplied the teacher with a preparation for spraying, which will assist in overcoming this trouble.

Miss Foisey has asked for a cheap wallpaper, to be applied overlapping on to the wood, also some paint for the woodwork. Miss Foisey, to be assured that it is applied properly has offer, with the assistance of her sister (who is on a temporary visit) to put on the paper etc.

I might say that Miss Foisey is managing very well with the children, she is well pleased with the school. There is an increase in pupils attending, compared to the last quarter of last term.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I beg to submit the following report of inspection of the St Regis Reserve made from June 14th to 17th, 1938.

The Chetland school house is in good state of repairs with the exception of both entrances, front and back. Also, both toilets need repairs which I would estimate at about $40.00. An addition to the school for teacher's quarters is now being considered as provided by an amount set aside in the estimates for that purpose.

Jude Thibault,

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his recent visit to the St. Regis Reserve Inspector Thibault states that both toilets at the Chetlain School require repairs. He estimates that the cost of these repairs will not exceed $40.00. Presumably this amount includes both material and labour. You may, therefore, arrange for the repairs required at a cost not exceeding the amount just mentioned.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the enclosed vouchers no. 732 and 733, for $13.48 and $2.35 in favour of Frank A. Francis and John Mitchell for work done at the Chetlain Indian Day school.

As the construction of the new addition to the school building shut off the light from the wash room, two windows were installed in the walls of the wash room which would admit light from the cloak rooms.

As the school coal bin was not large enough to hold coal required, a bin was installed in the cellar of the residence. Outbuildings slunged, cess pool covered, and seats of the school room put on slats for convenient moving for cleaning purposes.

Dear Sir:

At the time of Mr. Phelan's visit to this Agency last January the matter of having suitable drainage installed at the Chetlain school was brought up.

In the spring water comes into the cellar of the teacher's residence adjoining the school and as there is no drainage to take this water away it is felt that it would be advisable at this time to have the necessary work done.

After looking over the job it is estimated the following materials will be required:

- 1-4" trap hole $2.10

In connection with the above there will be also the labour angle to be taken care of. This work of course will be done by Indian labour. The trench will have to be dug below the level of the cellar floor and at a drop of approximately one foot for every ten feet in length to afford suitable drainage. It is estimated the total cost will not exceed $75.00.

Dear Sir:

Repairs, Chatlain School

While visiting the above school recently it was noted that minor repairs were needed on the coal bin and steps leading to the classroom on the South side of the building.

The coal bin and wood storage, which comprises three walls, is attached to the end of the school building proper. It is supported off the ground by loose stones piled on top of each other with the result that through frost heaving and the weight of fuel stored this building has become separated from the school. It will be necessary to put this building back into its proper position, level it and secure it well and put proper shoring underneath each corner in the form of stone and cement with intermediate piers between the corner ones.

The landing entrance to the classroom as well as some of the steps need replacement as the flooring is broken through and lumber will be required for this purpose. It is estimated that, along with some scrap lumber which is on hand, the following materials will be required to effect the necessary repairs at this school. In addition approximately $25.00 will be required for Indian labour. Materials will cost around $16.00.

(Materials)

CHENAIL SCHOOL

This school does not justify any repairs, being too old; attendance of twenty-four is too much for space available, and such conditions are far from being healthy. Sir,

Miss M. Kelly, teacher of the Chenaill Indian Day School, called at the Department today and requested a continuance of a grant allowed last year for living quarters for Miss Morris and herself. She was informed that the Department would continue to pay a rental at the rate of $10.00 a month for the living quarters for these two teachers and the necessary arrangements can be made with Mr. Sherrow by the teachers and yourself.

The Department will also pay for the fuel required for the use of the teachers in heating the rooms used by them but cannot provide fuel to heat any other part of the house in which they obtain accommodation. It should also be distinctly understood that no further arrangements will be made to provide any other equipment for living quarters for the teachers, as it is expected that the owners of the house will provide all the furniture and the other equipment required. You should arrange to supply a reasonable amount of fuel for heating purposes.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded from time to time covering the amount of the rent due at the above rate, namely, $10.00 a month.
